review.title: Interactions between Knowledge and Time in a First-Order Logic for Multi-Agent Systems: Completeness Results
review.abstract: We investigate a class of first-order temporal-epistemic logics for reasoning about multi-agent systems. We encode typical properties of systems including perfect recall, synchronicity, no learning, and having a unique initial state in terms of variants of quantified interpreted systems, a first-order extension of interpreted systems. We identify several monodic fragments of first-order temporal-epistemic logic and show their completeness with respect to their corresponding classes of quantified interpreted systems.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: While reactive systems (Pnueli, 1977) are traditionally specified with simple temporal logic, there is a well-established tradition in artificial intelligence (AI) and, in particular, in research with multiple agents (MAS) to apply more expressive languages. Much of this tradition is inspired by the earlier pioneering work in artificial intelligence by McCarthy (1979, 1990) and others aimed at adopting an "intentional attitude" (Dennett, 1987) when thinking about intelligent systems.

sections.heading: 1.2 The Present Contribution
sections.text: This paper extends the current state of the art in the field of first-order epistemic logic by introducing a family of verifiably complete calculations for a variety of quantified interpreted systems characterizing a number of characteristics, including perfect memory, non-learning, synchronicity, and a unique initial state. We prove the completeness of the presented first-order epistemic logic using a quasi-model construction previously applied (Hodkinson, Wolter, & Sakharyashev, 2002; Hodkinson et al., 2000) to prove the decidability of monodic fragments of first-order temporal logic (FoTL). Quasi models have also been applied to first-order temporal and epistemic logic (Sturm et al., 2000; Wolter & Sakharyashev et al., 2002).

sections.heading: 1.2.1 Structure of the Paper.
sections.text: In Section 2, we first introduce the primary temporal-epistemic languages Lm and LCm with general knowledge for a sentence Ag = {1,.., m} of agents. Then, we present the relevant classes of QIS as well as the monodic fragments of Lm and LCm. In Section 3, we present the axiomatizations for these classes of QIS, while the details of the completeness proofs are presented in Sections 4 and 5. Finally, in Section 6, we go into the results obtained and discuss possible extensions and future work.
